content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good work!

I like the puzzle, but it seems to be too straightforward with hints? But, well, it's not bad.

I think that you should mention that:
(1) heading is measured in degrees
(2) result should be rounded to the *nearest* integer

Also, probably the names `Angle` and `Distance` in formulas should be in lowercase? And consider adding spaces around `=` and `x`
And you shouldn't use `-` as bullets in list because it reads as `minus dx...`

Last one: probably you should restrict the shortest mode? The solution uses math heavily, so most of languages will need to import/include libraries for that.

I love the "real life scenario" :)

This phrasing of this is awkward (perhaps confusing):
"his friends are on roofs and can see each others to Juliet's house."

What do you mean by "others" and "to Juliet's house"?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i like it and i don't think it's hard,people who rejected probably are not good at math

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is manipulation of vector arithmetic, which can useful for multiple problems

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I reject the contribution because it is hard to be easily solved in less than  15min.
Maybe mention rounding the answers to the nearest integers in more than one place. I missed that part while reading the problem statement.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Je trouve que c'est trop long pour un clash of code, peut être un peu trop romancé

Goal section
* Please fix:
   • "want" to "wants"
   • "form" to "from"
   • "point" to "points"
* Suggest to specify that all distances are given in the same unit (as you do not specify whether the distance is in metres, kilometres, miles, etc).
* I think you may give an example (before the hints) of how the inputs are arranged. GIving an example will make it easier for the clash player to understand. For example,
<<Example>>
If the inputs are
10 3
30 4
-15 8
that means
• Romeo is able to see the roof of Friend 1's house at 10 degrees at a distance of 3 units.
• Friend 1 is able to see the roof of Friend 2's house at 30 degrees at a distance of 4 units.
• Friend 2 is able to see the roof of Juliet's house at -15 degrees at a distance of 8 units.

Cases
* I'm just curious: somehow all headings in the outputs are never negative?

Thanks.

My first contribution, every comment will be apreciated

Maybe a lot of typo, not a native english speaker

Edited, thank you a lot for your suggestions.

For the cases, I generated my number tending to create less distance heading under 0 than above. Do you think Ishould add a test where the result heading is negativ ?
The hints are there to help faster resolution. Did you try to solve it ? How many time did it takes ?
Added 2 other mention to the expected rounded result

Thank you for the approbation ! 

Is there something I may change to improve the contribution ?
Thank you for the approbation !

Edited this phrase to clear the confusion

Thank you for the feedback
Got aproved before I can edit the statement, thank you for the feedback
Thank you !
you're welcome. Can you please commebt your thoughts about my contribution?? Thanks in advance!

The one thing that would make the explanation easier is to explain the example input. Like in order to get to Juliet, the paper plane must pass through the houses in order of the sequence presented. So, it will first need to go to Friend 1 (10 degrees, 3 unit from start point), then Friend 2 (30 degrees, 4 units from Friend 1), then to Juliet (-15 degrees, 8 units of Friend 2).

I personally found the contribution easy enough to understand right now.

You may add tests and validators if you think it is a good idea. But in that case, it would be better to draw the player's attention by specifying the possibility of a negative heading angle in the statement.

Thanks.
